fly.translation[0].definitions[0].exampl: She’s flying back to the States tomorrow.
Will you take the train there or fly?
Maurice is nervous about flying, so he usually travels overland.
Lewis stopped off in Jamaica before flying on to Toronto.
The prime minister will be flying to Delhi later today for a three-day visit.
He was arrested at Heathrow after flying from Brussels airport.
fly.translation[0].definitions[1].defini: if a plane, spacecraft etc flies, it moves through the air
fly.translation[0].definitions[1].exampl: The plane was attacked as it flew over restricted airspace.
fly.translation[0].definitions[2].defini: to be at the controls of a plane and direct it as it flies
fly.translation[0].definitions[2].exampl: She was the first woman to fly Concorde.
The pilot was instructed to fly the plane to Montreal airport.
Sonny learnt to fly when he was 15.
fly.translation[0].definitions[3].defini: to take goods or people somewhere by plane
fly.translation[0].definitions[3].exampl: The injured boy was flown by air ambulance to the Royal London Hospital.
US planes have been flying food and medical supplies into the area.
fly something into/out of etc something
fly.translation[0].definitions[4].defini: to use a particular airline or use a particular type of ticket when you travel by plane
fly.translation[0].definitions[4].exampl: Millions of passengers fly British Airways every year.
fly.translation[0].definitions[5].defini: to cross a particular ocean or area of sea in a plane
fly.translation[0].definitions[5].exampl: Who was the first person to fly the Atlantic?
fly.translation[0].definitions[6].defini: to move through the air using wings
fly.translation[0].definitions[6].exampl: The mother bird will feed her chicks until they are able to fly.
The evening air was clouded with mosquitoes and other flying insects.
The robin shook its feathers and flew away.
At that moment, a wasp flew in through the open window.
fly.translation[0].definitions[7].defini: to move somewhere quickly and suddenly
fly.translation[0].definitions[7].exampl: Rachel’s hand flew to her mouth.
Ellen flew across the room and greeted her uncle with a kiss.
The door flew open and a child rushed out.
fly.translation[0].definitions[8].defini: to move quickly and suddenly through the air
fly.translation[0].definitions[8].exampl: There was a loud explosion, and suddenly there was glass flying everywhere.
William hit Jack on the head and sent his glasses flying.
The ball bounced off the wall and went flying into the garden next door.
fly.translation[0].definitions[9].defini: to make a kite fly in the air
fly.translation[0].definitions[9].exampl: In the park people were walking their dogs or flying their kites.
fly.translation[0].definitions[10].defin: to move freely and loosely in the air
fly.translation[0].definitions[10].examp: Harriet ran after him, her hair flying behind her.
fly.translation[0].definitions[11].defin: if a flag flies, or if you fly it, it is fixed to the top of a tall pole so that it can be easily seen
fly.translation[0].definitions[11].examp: After the invasion, people were forbidden to fly their national flag.
The flags were flying cheerfully in the breeze.
The government ordered that all flags should be flown at half mast (=halfway down the pole, in order to express public sadness at someone’s death).
fly.translation[0].definitions[12].defin: to leave somewhere in order to escape
fly.translation[0].definitions[12].examp: By the time the police arrived, the men had flown.
fly.translation[0].definitions[13].defin: a plan that will fly will be successful and useful
fly.translation[0].definitions[13].examp: News is that the plan for the new hotel isn’t going to fly.
Fly belongs to a group of verbs where the same noun can be the subject of the verb or its object
In this sentence, ‘the plane’ is the object of fly
He flew the plane across the desert
In this sentence, ‘the plane’ is the subject of fly
The plane flew across the desert
fly.translation[1].definitions[0].defini: a small flying insect with two wings
fly.translation[1].definitions[0].exampl: There were flies buzzing all around us.
fly.translation[1].definitions[1].defini: the part at the front of a pair of trousers which you can open
fly.translation[1].definitions[1].exampl: He quickly did up his fly.
fly.translation[1].definitions[2].defini: a hook that is made to look like a fly and is used for catching fish
fly.translation[2].definitions[0].defini: to hit a ball in baseball high into the air
fly.translation[3].definitions[0].exampl: Wear something really fly for your Friday date.
fly.translation[3].definitions[1].exampl: He’s a bit of a fly character.
fly.translation[4].definitions[0].exampl: From Belfast, British Airways Cargo flies to London Heathrow, Manchester and Glasgow.
Mr McGovern always flies economy class.
fly.translation[4].definitions[1].defini: to take goods or people to a place by plane
fly.translation[4].definitions[1].exampl: It was more cost-effective to fly the chemicals direct to each country.
A waiting helicopter flew the president to his next meeting.
fly.translation[4].definitions[2].defini: if a product or idea flies, it succeeds
fly.translation[4].definitions[2].exampl: We were never confident the system was going to fly.
A product which the market has clearly rejected cannot be made to fly
fly.translation[4].definitions[3].defini: to be or do the opposite of what most people think is reasonable, sensible or normal
fly.translation[4].definitions[3].exampl: A sales tax would fly in the face of EU moves towards greater standardisation of indirect taxes.
She made a virtue of flying in the face of business convention.
